title: Financial Teamwork
description: Assess how well you function as a financial team

questions.text: I feel like we're on the same team when it comes to money.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling like financial teammates—rather than opponents or strangers—creates partnership. This 'us vs. the problem' mindset helps you tackle challenges together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel like teammates, explore what creates that sense. Is it about decision-making? Communication? Different goals?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of being on the same team is foundational for financial partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make you feel more like financial teammates?

questions.text: I believe my partner and I complement each other's financial strengths.

therapeutic.rationale: Partners often have different financial strengths—one may be better at budgeting, another at earning, another at researching purchases. Seeing these as complementary builds team spirit.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't see complementary strengths, explore what strengths each person brings. They may not recognize their own contributions.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual recognition of complementary strengths creates appreciation and effective teamwork.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial strengths does your partner bring that you lack?

questions.text: I trust my partner to handle certain financial responsibilities.

therapeutic.rationale: Delegating financial responsibilities requires trust. Couples who can divide financial labor effectively function as a more efficient team.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust levels in delegation may reflect different experiences. The less-trusting partner may need more transparency or different task division.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust in delegation allows you to divide financial labor effectively.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial tasks would you trust your partner to handle? What would you prefer to keep?

questions.text: I feel we communicate well about money matters.

therapeutic.rationale: Financial communication is a specific skill. Couples who communicate well about money keep each other informed, make decisions together, and avoid surprises.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceptions of communication quality suggest room for improvement. The less satisfied partner can identify what's missing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared satisfaction with financial communication indicates an effective system.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would improve how you and your partner communicate about money?

questions.text: I believe we make better financial decisions together than alone.

therapeutic.rationale: Belief that partnership improves decisions reflects appreciation for what you each bring. Couples who believe this are more likely to consult each other.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't see the partnership value, explore why. Does one partner dominate decisions? Does the other not engage?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual belief in the value of partnership decision-making strengthens your team.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do your partner's perspectives improve your financial decisions?
